title: Many journalists and fans think Pep Guardiola reinvented football, so I'm enjoying seeing him tested at Manchester City
text:
Sport Opinion Many journalists and fans think Pep Guardiola reinvented football, so I'm enjoying seeing him tested at Manchester City The abject failure of the Blues' Champions League exit to Monaco shows the deified Spaniard for what he really is — just another good manager Share This season is proving that Guardiola is good, not a God (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Share Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
For Manchester City , there are no excuses. 
Their Champions League defeat to Monaco is nothing but abject failure. 
It is abject failure because they didn’t lose to a team who will probably go on to lift the European Cup in June. 
Monaco are a good side, but the French league has generally provided good one-off teams such as Paris Saint-Germain, Marseille and Monaco in the past, and very rarely do they go on and threaten finals and win tournaments. 
To concede six goals in two games against them is unforgivable — if Manuel Pellegrini had that team and squad and let in six goals he’d have been sacked. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Pep Guardiola speaks after crashing out of the Champions League Share this video Watch Next 
People tell me Pep Guardiola inherited a poor defence. 
But it was his decision to get rid of Joe Hart , who would have kept more clean sheets and made more match-winning, and match-saving, stops than either Willy Caballero or Claudio Bravo , almost immediately. 
It was also his decision to play a style of football from the back and the goalkeeper which, against very good sides, invites and puts you under pressure. 
And it was Guardiola who made not a £5million gamble, not a £10m gamble but a FIFTY million one to buy John Stones . 
He is a decent footballer but not on the same planet as an Alan Hansen or Mark Lawrenson, who he has been compared to — and he cannot defend. Hart is a better keeper than Caballero or Bravo, but was bombed out on loan (Photo: PA Wire) Read More Rio Ferdinand says he felt sorry for John Stones during City's loss in Monaco 
So when you go into the second leg of a Champions League knockout tie with Stones and career left-back Aleksandar Kolarov as your two centre-halves, you are asking for trouble. 
Surely a world class coach would recognise that his Achilles heel is his defence and do something to protect it, rather play five attackers? 
With City 5-3 up going into Wednesday night, he should have been saying, ‘Monaco ran out of steam late in the first game. Let’s keep things tight maybe for 60, 65 minutes and then turn up the gas, make one or two tactical substitutions and go and win the game 1-0 or 2-0.’ 
They were more than capable of doing that. 
Lots of journalists and fans think Guardiola has reinvented football. 
For me, he was just a guy who inherited Lionel Messi and built around him with some very good players from Barcelona’s B side and their Academy, and they became a world class team. City's gameplan for the second leg against Monaco was hugely naive (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Read More Guardiola blames Man City's lack of European experience after last-16 exit 
He then went to Bayern Munich, who have a 60 to 70 per cent chance of winning the German title every season, and failed to make a dent on the Champions League. 
In terms of what he does at teams that aren’t ready-built for him, he looks distinctly average. 
Conceding six goals in two games is not elite level football or defending. 
And who has Guardiola made better this season? I can’t think of one City player over 20 or 30 games. 
Fabian Delph came out with a bonkers comment in July, saying he had learnt more in the first three weeks under Guardiola than he had in his whole career to that point. 
That may well be the case, but I have yet to see that translated onto the pitch by any of the players Guardiola has had for almost a year now. It's amazing how much harder management is when you don't have truly great players (Photo: Getty) Read More McDONNELL: Guardiola needs a whole new defence if City are serious about Europe 
This season, we are seeing him struggling and having to come to terms with one of the world’s toughest leagues. 
And I’m enjoying it, because when I was told, as his Barcelona team were beating all-comers, that he was the best manager in the world, I didn’t see it. 
What I saw was a good manager with a really good crop of players who all came together at the same time. 
Did he have to get them motivated and playing in a system? Yes he did, but at Man City you have to try different things. 
You have to get people working better on set-pieces, on individual defending, on defending as a team, on keeping the ball better even — something Guardiola is supposed to be amazing at. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
